executive_summary: Commercial remodelers have expanded modestly over the past five years. Even amid interest rate hikes, the overall commercial building market recovering from the pandemic enabled remodelers to recover. Still, declines in office building construction have subdued growth. Industry-wide revenue has been growing at a CAGR of 0.1% over the past five years and is expected to total $44.1 billion in 2024, when revenue will drop by an estimated 1.2%. The rise of remote work has greatly hindered renovations to office buildings...

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Remodelers Have Endured Headwinds, But There Have Been Bright Spots
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: High interest rates and recent declines in corporate profit have discouraged remodeling expenditures. Still, remodelers providing non-discretionary work like maintenance and repairs and the overall commercial market recovering from pandemic-induced declines have shielded companies from massive downturns late.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Commercial remodelers will enjoy accelerated growth over the next five years
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: More favorable economic conditions, like higher disposable income and corporate profit growth, will promote expansion in downstream markets. Still, office rental vacancies only inching down over the next five years will threaten remodelers. The Inflation Reduction Act will spur growth through tax incentives and grants to improve the energy efficiency of commercial buildings.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: MORE FAVORABLE ECONOMIC CONDITIONS TO BOLSTER EXPANSION
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Accelerated growth in disposable income and corporate profit over the next five years will greatly benefit commercial property remodelers. Interest rate cuts will trigger the expansion of stores, restaurants and other commercial buildings, providing a positive impetus for commercial property remodelers.

The Inflation Reduction Act provides tax credits of $1.88 per square foot to the owners of commercial properties placed in service before 2023 that invest in increasing the energy efficiency of buildings. While there are also incentives for new commercial buildings, tax credits applying for renovations will bolster growth for commercial property remodelers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: PROFIT TO INCH UP AS COSTS REMAIN HIGH
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next five years, falling interest rates will spur an upswing in commercial property remodeling activity. Still, interest rate cuts pushing up overall construction activity will continue to drive up purchase costs as material shortages persist.

industry_definition: This industry primarily undertakes remodeling construction for commercial buildings. Remodeling work includes additions, alterations, reconstruction,...
key_trends: The Inflation Reduction Act will catalyze growth
No company has gained more than 5.0% of the market
Commercial property remodelers get public and private help
Increased competition for business stunted profit growth
Commercial remodelers face rising purchase costs
The Southeast's high population draws remodelers
Major cities in the Mid-Atlantic, specifically New York and Philadelphia, draw remodelers
Supply chain issues and growth in e-commerce boosted remodeling investments

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market comprises shopping centers, malls and general merchandise stores, restaurants, bars and fast-food outlets, drug stores, building supply stores and other retail outlets.
This market comprises remodeling services on office buildings.
This market comprises work in hotels, motels and resorts.

This market comprises work in warehouses and storage facilities. Supply chain woes led to increased investment in warehouses and storage facilities to expand efficiencies amid supply shocks, promoting growth in this market. Also, strong growth in e-commerce sales has hiked investments in warehouses.
This market comprises sports facilities and gyms, private clubs and social centers, movie theaters, theme parks, casinos and similar structures.
This market comprises work on nonresidential farm buildings, including barns, silos, storage spaces and other commercial structures, like parking garages.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Residential Building Construction in the UK
Commercial and Industrial Building Construction in New Zealand

products_and_services.product_description: This service segment includes fencing, roofing, paint, windows, doors and other related services. Growth from exterior additions and alterations has been stable as these services are essential for building safety and structural integrity. Downstream customers have also turned to exterior alteration services to restore older buildings, bolstering this segment.
This segment comprises upgrades and repairs for plumbing, pipes, electrical systems, air conditioning, heating, garbage disposal, insulation and other related infrastructure.

This segment comprises disaster repair services, including restoration, reconstruction and mold remediation. This segment has expanded after several major hurricanes and other natural disasters in recent years that contributed to the costliest damages on record.
This segment comprises miscellaneous commercial building infrastructure construction services, like installing fencing, parking meters, parking gates and other facilities.

tier_1_suppliers: Electrical Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Ready-Mix Concrete Manufacturing in the US
Construction Machinery Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Consumer spending significantly shapes demand across the economy, directly affecting commercial property remodelers. As consumer expenditure grows, it stimulates corporate profit and enhances demand for downstream goods and services. This situation prompts companies to escalate production, necessitating the expansion of commercial spaces like offices, warehouses and retail outlets. A surge in consumer spending can result in an increased need for commercial property remodelers.

business_locations.location_description: Many remodeling businesses set up shop in the Southeast. The region's large population and numerous urban areas provide a steady need for construction and maintenance services. Florida stands out with a high density of commercial property remodelers. It's the country's third most populous state and is frequently struck by hurricanes, creating a consistent need for repair services often met by these remodeling businesses.

Commercial remodelers are especially attracted to California because of its well-developed commercial property market, driven by high consumer demand. The large population equals more stores, office buildings and other business spaces, which invariably require upgrading or remodeling. This ensures a steady demand for commercial remodeling services and pushes up establishments in the West. Los Angeles, San Francisco and San Diego are commercial construction hubs in California, reflecting the state's status as the most populous in the US. This trend attracts commercial remodelers, as a densely populated region typically requires more commercial building construction.

The Mid-Atlantic region, the country's third most populated region, provides a significant marketplace for commercial remodelers. The density of potential clients drives remodelers to the area. New York and Pennsylvania, some of the largest cities in the Mid-Atlantic region, are particularly attractive to these businesses. New York ranks fourth nationwide in housing commercial remodelers who offer services to the myriad shops and office buildings scattered across its cities. The vast commercial markets in cities such as Manhattan and Philadelphia remain a magnet for remodeling businesses, solidifying the Mid-Atlantic region's position as a hot spot for commercial remodeling.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The safety of workers in commercial construction is paramount, with stringent standards established by OSHA mandated in Title 29 of the Federal Regulations Part 1926. Contractors are required to provide protective attire and ensure a hazard-free environment. In addition, there are strict adherence rules regarding pollution control, land use, community disturbance and occupational health, with violations risking workers' safety and potential legal consequences.

Commercial remodelers must master a bewildering array of rules and regulations. These include building, residential, mechanical, plumbing and electric codes and fire and accessibility codes, all typically updated by the International Code Council. They also have to abide by state, local and zoning codes. For instance, some remodeling jobs may be exempt from needing permits if they don't alter the structure or decrease natural light or ventilation.

To curb the spread of COVID-19, state and local governments applied stringent social distancing rules. The impact forced a shutdown on major sectors of the economy, with exceptions for vital services. Commercial contractors were among the exceptions deemed 'essential' and allowed to operate under specific health and safety measures. For instance, construction projects resumed with firm mandates on protective gear usage and maintaining distancing norms on-site.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition is fierce in commercial remodeling
basis_points.basis_description: Remodelers vie on varied fronts like project quality, speed, technological skill, prestige and cost, all of which distinguish one provider from another in this crowded market.

basis_points.basis_title: Little competition due to niche services
basis_points.basis_description: Commercial remodelers face little competition because of their niche services. Remodeling commercial properties are typically more complex than residential jobs, making it less common for owners to attempt do-it-yourself projects.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Most remodelers are small local establishments
concentration_points.concentration_description: Most commercial remodelers are small establishments operating within a local or regional sphere. The large number of non-employers subcontracting labor keeps market share concentration low.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Difficult for smaller companies to expand
concentration_points.concentration_description: It's difficult for smaller companies to operate outside their sphere as they must compete with remodelers with well-established reputations and strong connections in those markets.

A handful of larger contractors have the capital resources to operate nationally. Still, expanding into regions where a remodeler has no established reputation is risky since most companies generate business through word-of-mouth referrals.
Although some larger commercial property remodelers expand into other regions, they still can't amass considerable market share because of demand dispersion throughout the US.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Supply Chain Woes and Labor Shortages Have Pushed Up Purchase Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Commercial remodelers purchase tangible goods like ready-mix concrete, glass, structural steel, concrete panels, structural timber, metal cladding, aluminum fitting and electrical installations. Purchase costs also include subcontracted labor for concreting contractors, structural steel erectors, plumbers, electrical contractors and crane operators.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Office building remodeling is the largest service segment for commercial remodelers, so the amount of remodeling work done on office buildings greatly impacts volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The Level of Consumer Spending Impacts Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: A key service segment for commercial property remodelers is alteration and expansion services to small businesses, supermarkets, shopping malls, department stores and other commercial properties.

During low interest rates, downstream markets are more incentivized to invest in remodeling and alterations, promoting growth, pushing up revenue and benefiting commercial property remodelers. Even amid the outbreak of COVID-19 in 2020, remodeling activity increased, bolstered by low rates.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The Use of Laser and GPS-Equipped Machines
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Commercial remodelers using laser and GPS-equipped machines can simplify complex building processes. This equipment enables remodelers to speed up project times, lower costs and improve building quality.

Commercial remodelers strengthen efficiencies in buildings by better insulating walls and using double glazing or low emissive film in windows. The use of sustainable materials in commercial remodeling is on the rise as consumers are increasingly concerned about climate change.

FAQs.question: Does your company serve as a general contractor or third-party subcontractor on most projects?
FAQs.answer: The text does not directly answer whether the company serves as a general contractor or third-party subcontractor.

FAQs.question: Does your company make use of subcontractors to save on wage costs? Roughly, what percent of revenue is consumed by wages?
FAQs.answer: The text states that by relying more heavily on subcontractors rather than in-house employees, contractors are able to spend less on wage payments. However, it does not provide a specific percentage of revenue consumed by wages.

FAQs.question: Does your company typically rent or own equipment for projects?
FAQs.answer: The text states that heavy equipment used for additions is typically rented or brought by subcontracted machinery operators, while capital investment is mainly allocated towards purchases of vehicles and computers used in sales offices and for project design.

FAQs.question: In light of increasing wage costs, has your company considered using new technologies to boost productivity or reduce total employment?
FAQs.answer: The text mentions that logistic management software enables operators to efficiently align equipment and workers from a remote location, and has helped transform complex building processes by speeding up project completion and lowering costs.

FAQs.question: Has your company considered using building information modeling (BIM) to gain a competitive advantage?
FAQs.answer: The text states that BIM allows construction companies to view every aspect of a construction project in vivid 3-D before construction begins, and BIM software can determine how a proposed change will affect subcontractor costs and scheduling, allowing contractors to create more accurate budgets.

FAQs.question: Has complying with new energy-efficiency rules in various building codes driven up costs? How has your company offset these higher costs?
FAQs.answer: The text mentions that demand for energy-efficient buildings has climbed, in part due to a surge in federal tax credits for energy-efficient buildings and state government standards supporting improved energy efficiency, which has benefited commercial property remodelers. However, it does not specify how companies have offset potential higher costs from complying with these rules.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met on and off the construction site?
FAQs.answer: The text states that health and safety regulations require workers to wear protective clothing and helmets on-site and that safe conditions are provided for them, and OSHA enforces standards contained in Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 1926.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare with your competitors'?
FAQs.answer: The text mentions that low fixed costs enable some contractors to reduce expenses quickly, as most employees and capital costs are based on a per-project basis, improving profitability. However, it does not provide a direct comparison of profit margins to competitors.

FAQs.question: How has your company adapted to the effects of price-based competition?
FAQs.answer: The text states that intensified price competition induced by fluctuations in office rental yields hikes price-based competition, and developing a strong reputation can shield contractors from this competition.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain skilled employees? How frequently do you employ subcontractors to maintain costs?
FAQs.answer: The text mentions that successful remodeling companies have access to a pool of reliable tradespeople and subcontractors who are available on a per-project basis. However, it does not provide details on how companies attract and retain skilled employees or the frequency of employing subcontractors.

FAQs.question: What measures do you have in place to reduce operational costs? Are you considering any new cost-saving measures?
FAQs.answer: The text states that successful remodeling companies have effective cost controls, with access to low-cost input products to ensure competitive pricing. However, it does not specify any particular measures for reducing operational costs or new cost-saving measures being considered.

FAQs.question: How do you advertise your services? Does your company have a good word-of-mouth reputation?
FAQs.answer: The text mentions that successful remodeling companies have a strong marketing department to generate publicity and new contracts, suggesting advertising of services. It also states that developing a strong reputation can shield contractors from price-based competition, implying the importance of word-of-mouth reputation.

FAQs.question: How have trends in corporate profit affected your revenue? How do you monitor and respond to profit trends in the industries of your clients?
FAQs.answer: The text states that as corporate profit rises, companies are more able to open new locations and hire additional staff, driving demand for commercial remodeling. However, it does not provide details on how companies monitor and respond to profit trends in client industries.

FAQs.question: How many of your clients finance the costs of your services? How much will higher interest rates add to the cost of your projects?
FAQs.answer: The text mentions that most remodeling purchases and construction are financed by commercial loans, which are related to the yield on the 10-year Treasury bond, and low rates decrease the cost of borrowing funds to finance remodeling projects. However, it does not specify how many clients finance costs or quantify the impact of higher interest rates.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor trends in disposable income and consumer spending? How do you maintain profitability when consumer spending declines?
FAQs.answer: The text states that consumer spending influences demand for business throughout the economy, and as consumers spend more, demand for downstream goods and services rises, encouraging companies to expand and strengthen production, spurring demand for more commercial building space. However, it does not mention how companies maintain profitability when consumer spending declines.
